prior_works.title: Continuous Local Search (CLS)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s CLS-completeness results are proved within the CLS framework introduced in this work, which formalizes continuous local search problems and provides the target notion of completeness used by the authors.

prior_works.title: Complexity of finding stationary points via gradient-based local search (CLS-completeness)
prior_works.authors: John Fearnley, Paul W. Goldberg, Rahul Savani, et al.
prior_works.role: Technical tool linking first-order stationarity to CLS
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This line of work establishes CLS-completeness for finding first-order stationary points, which the paper leverages to classify the complexity of computing symmetric first-order equilibria in symmetric min-max problems.

prior_works.title: Local min-max points and first-order equilibria in nonconvex–nonconcave minimax optimization
prior_works.authors: Chi Jin, Praneeth Netrapalli, Michael I. Jordan
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By formalizing appropriate first-order notions of equilibrium for nonconvex–nonconcave min-max problems, this work provides the equilibrium concept that the paper studies under symmetry and analyzes from a complexity perspective.

prior_works.title: Graphical games (and the polymatrix representation) and their computational complexity
prior_works.authors: Michael Kearns, Michael L. Littman, Satinder Singh
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s hardness constructions are confined to polymatrix games; this foundational framework underpins representing multi-player interactions via pairwise payoffs, which the authors exploit to preserve structure in their reductions.

prior_works.title: On the complexity of equilibria in polymatrix games
prior_works.role: Techniques for encoding constraints in polymatrix games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Prior techniques for building hardness within the polymatrix model inform the paper’s design of reductions that retain polymatrix structure while enforcing symmetry via an adversarial player.

prior_works.title: Team zero-sum games: modeling and equilibrium computation in adversarial team settings
prior_works.authors: Giovanni Farina, Omar El Farol Kroer, Tuomas Sandholm
prior_works.role: Model formalization for adversarial team games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work formalizes team zero-sum games and equilibrium notions for a team versus an adversary, providing the game-theoretic setting and baseline tools that the paper specializes to the 3-player adversarial team case.

prior_works.title: The complexity of symmetric equilibria in min-max optimization
prior_works.authors: Yannick Hollender, Lucas Maystre, Vaishnavh Nagarajan
prior_works.role: Immediate hardness source and open question antecedent
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper reduces from their CLS-hardness for symmetric ε-Nash in symmetric identical-payoff two-player games and resolves their open question by showing hardness persists even when the constructed instances are polymatrix.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contributions—proving CLS-completeness for ε-Nash equilibria in 3-player adversarial team games and classifying the complexity of symmetric first-order equilibria in symmetric min-max problems—rest on three pillars: the CLS framework, symmetric-equilibrium hardness for identical-payoff games, and polymatrix-structured reductions.

CLS, introduced by Daskalakis and Papadimitriou, provides the ambient complexity class and completeness notions that the authors target. Recent advances showing CLS-completeness for finding first-order stationary points via gradient-based local search directly connect first-order equilibrium computation to CLS, enabling the paper’s classification of symmetric first-order equilibria. On the equilibrium concept side, the local min-max framework of Jin, Netrapalli, and Jordan supplies the first-order notions of equilibrium (stationarity and symmetry) that the paper studies in nonconvex–nonconcave min-max settings.

The reduction backbone leverages hardness for symmetric ε-Nash equilibria in symmetric, identical-payoff two-player games established by recent work of Hollender, Maystre, and Nagarajan. The present paper ingeniously employs a single adversarial player to enforce symmetry without distorting payoffs, transporting that hardness to 3-player adversarial team games. Finally, by engineering the reduction entirely within the polymatrix model—rooted in the graphical-game formalism of Kearns, Littman, and Singh and informed by techniques for encoding constraints in polymatrix games—the authors settle the open question posed by Hollender et al., showing that hardness persists under stringent pairwise-interaction structure.
